public CopyOfTaskEngine(java.lang.String platform,

Create a new task engine with given default values for platform and deviceType. Note that how platforms and deviceTypes are associated with tasks is outside the scope of the standard, and is not addressed by this implementation.

parse

public TaskModel parse(java.lang.String from)
Load, parse and return task model from specified XML document. Loads the first toplevel element. NB: This implementation does not support forward or circular namespace references using prefixes. Thus task models must be loaded in order such that all external references to task model namespaces refer to already loaded models.

Parameters:
from - string identifying url, system resource (without leading slash) or file containing XML document
See Also:
load(String)

Set object to be called after new task model loaded.

public TaskModel load(java.lang.String from)
Load, parse, validate and return task model from specified XML document. Validation errors written to error output.

Returns:
null if validation errors or unable to validate
See Also:

copy

public Task copy(Task task)
Make a copy in this engine of given task instance, possibly from another engine. Recursively copies task values in slots.

Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if task class does not exist in this engine

setStart

public void setStart(long start)
Set the start time to be used for 'when' slot in verbose version of Instance.toString(). If start time is greater than zero, then shows 'when' in seconds since start time, rather than UTC in milliseconds.

Parameters:
start - - start time in milliseconds (e.g., System.currentTimeMillis())

getFocus

public Plan getFocus()
Return the current focus in the task tree, or null if no focus.

Note that this is not the discourse concept of focus (cf. Collagen), but rather a much simpler "execution" focus. For example, there is no focus stack. Also, the focus will not usually not be on a done plan. Management of the focus is the responsibility of the application using the engine (e.g., the Guide), with the exception of addTop(Plan) and removeTop(Plan), as documented.

Note also that this is not the same as the "next" live action, since in a partially ordered plan, there may be several next actions to choose from. The current focus will usually have the next live actions as its children.

See Also:
setFocus(Plan)

setFocus

public boolean setFocus(Plan focus)
Shift focus to the given plan or null.

Returns:
true iff this is an "unexpected focus shift" in the sense of Lesh, Rich & Sidner's UM'01 paper, i.e., we are leaving the current focus when it is started but not done.
See Also:
getFocus()

pop

public void pop()
Set focus to (possibly null) parent of current focus.

newFocus

public Plan newFocus(Plan plan)
Return first ancestor of given plan which is live or has live descendants, stopping at toplevel plan containing given plan, or null if none.

explainBest

public Plan explainBest(Task task,
                        boolean onlyLive)
Find the plan in current task tree, if any, which best explains given task (i.e., to which given task contributes).

Returns:
plan which explains this task or null, if none
See Also:
explain(Task,boolean)

explain

public java.util.List<Plan> explain(Task task,
                                    boolean onlyLive)
Return list of plans in task tree which explain given task, searching in the following categories, in order:
  1. within current focus
  2. within current toplevel plan
  3. any toplevel plan
If plans are found in one category, search does not continue to next category.

Parameters:
onlyLive - only search live plans

ambiguous

protected void ambiguous(java.util.List<?> explanations)

getTops

public java.util.List<TaskClass> getTops()
Returns task classes which can serve as root of plan recognition. Typically this is because they do not contribute to any other task classes. However, this can be overridden by @top property in library.
